The nutritionist stood at the end of the bottled water aisle of a local grocery store and asked residents to respond to the question, “Do you usually drink at least <math alttext="24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces of water per day?”(a) Explain how the nutritionist’s sampling method might have introduced bias and describe how the bias might affect the point estimate of <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the proportion of all residents from the town who would respond “yes” to the question.

frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.A nutritionist is interested in investigating the health habits of residents of a certain large town. The nutritionist stood at the end of the bottled water aisle of a local grocery store and asked residents to respond to the question, “Do you usually drink at least <math alttext="24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces of water per day?”(a) Explain how the nutritionist’s sampling method might have introduced bias and describe how the bias might affect the point estimate of <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the proportion of all residents from the town who would respond “yes” to the question.

Suppose that <math alttext="38%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>38</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> of residents from the town drink at least <math alttext="24" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces of water per day. Let <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the total number of residents selected at random, one at a time, from the town when the first resident who drinks at least <math alttext="24" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces of water per day is selected. The graph shows the probability distribution of <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. (b) Calculate and interpret the expected value of <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) Describe a simulation process that could be conducted to estimate the value of <math alttext="the probability of, open parenthesis, W is less than or equal to 3, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>W</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

A fitness instructor at a gym in the town is interested in examining whether the <math alttext="500" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> members of the gym have different health habits from the overall population of residents of the town. A random sample of <math alttext="40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> members will be selected from the gym and each member will be asked to report whether they usually drink at least <math alttext="24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces of water per day.(d) If the instructor uses a stratified random sampling procedure to select the sample, identify an effective variable on which to stratify. Explain your reasoning.

Assume the conditions for inference are met. A <math alttext="98" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>98</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval for the proportion of all members from this gym who would report that they usually drink at least <math alttext="24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces of water per day was computed to be <math alttext="0.375 plus or minus 0.178" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.375</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.178</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(e) Does the confidence interval provide convincing statistical evidence that members of this gym have different health habits from the overall population of residents of the town? Justify your answer.
